transcript: Just got off a great call with Mike Thompson at Reliable Mechanical. They're a 35-person commercial HVAC shop in Phoenix, been running ServiceTitan for two years now. Mike said the pricing has gotten insane, like they're paying almost three times what they started at. Really interested in our job costing, said that's the biggest gap they have right now. They're also frustrated that their techs don't use the mobile app because it's too complicated. Mike said quote 'my guys just want to clock in and see their jobs, not navigate a spaceship.' Wants to do a demo next Tuesday, bringing his ops manager.

key_quotes: my guys just want to clock in and see their jobs, not navigate a spaceship

transcript: Quick call with Premier Plumbing, talked to Dave who I think is the GM. Smaller shop, maybe 12-15 people, mostly residential service in the Denver area. They're literally running everything on paper and QuickBooks, like literally paper work orders. Dave knows they need to modernize but said his techs are older and he's worried about adoption. Mentioned they looked at Housecall Pro last year but never pulled the trigger. No real urgency, said maybe they'll think about it after their busy season. I'll check back in Q1.

pain_points: worried about tech adoption with older techs

transcript: So that was an interesting one. ABC Services, they're kind of a hybrid - do both HVAC and plumbing. Talked to Sarah the owner and her ops guy Marcus was on too. About 45 people between the two divisions, mix of commercial and residential work in Atlanta. They tried Jobber maybe two years ago, total disaster, half the team refused to use it and they eventually gave up. So now they're gun shy. Sarah said she can't afford another failed implementation. But she also said inventory tracking is killing them, like they have no idea what's on the trucks. Marcus mentioned they're losing maybe 50K a year in parts they can't account for. That got their attention when I mentioned our inventory module. They want to see specifically how that works. Sarah asked about implementation support, like hand holding through the transition. Setting up a call next week to dig into that more.

extraction.next_step_notes: dig into inventory and implementation support

transcript: Really good discovery with Central Electric today. Big shop, like 80-90 people, commercial electrical work all over the DFW area. Talked to their CFO Jennifer and the operations director Tom. They're on Sage for accounting and some custom Access database thing for service that Tom built himself years ago. Jennifer is the driver here, she's frustrated because she can't get real job costing numbers out of their current setup. She said and I quote 'I'm basically guessing on every bid because I don't know our true costs.' Tom seemed a bit defensive about his system but even he admitted it's falling apart. They have a service side doing maybe 40% of revenue that's basically untracked. Jennifer asked about our reporting and I showed her a few screenshots, she got really excited. They want a full demo with their whole leadership team, like 6 people. Trying to get it scheduled for the week after next. This could be a big one, probably 50-60 licenses.

pain_points: can't get real job costing numbers
extraction.next_step_notes: full demo with 6 person leadership team, potential 50-60 licenses
key_quotes: I'm basically guessing on every bid because I don't know our true costs

transcript: Ugh, that was a waste of time. Valley Plumbing, talked to some guy named Rick, couldn't even figure out if he was the owner or a manager. Maybe 8 people, residential drain cleaning mostly. They're using Housecall Pro and seem totally fine with it. Rick was really just fishing for pricing to use as leverage in his renewal negotiation. Asked a bunch of questions about features and then admitted he's not really looking to switch, just wants to tell Housecall Pro he's got other options. Whatever, marked it as closed lost in the CRM.

extraction.next_step_notes: not actually looking to switch, using us for price leverage

transcript: Just finished with Martinez Mechanical, fire protection contractor down in Houston. Talked to Carlos Martinez, the owner, and his daughter Maria who handles the office. Really interesting setup - they're 100% commercial sprinkler systems, new construction and inspection services. About 30 people, maybe 20 in the field. Currently doing everything in Excel and paper inspection forms. Carlos has been in business 30 years and never used software beyond QuickBooks. But Maria is pushing hard to modernize, she showed me their paper filing system and it's like, boxes and boxes of inspection reports. They have compliance issues because they can't find documentation when they need it. The AHJ almost dinged them on a project last month because they couldn't produce the right paperwork. Maria said 'dad we almost lost our license over this.' Carlos finally agreed they need something. Main thing they need is inspection tracking with photo documentation and being able to pull up history instantly. Also interested in scheduling for their inspection routes. Maria is the champion here, Carlos will sign off if she's happy. Doing a demo focused on inspections next Thursday.

extraction.next_step_notes: demo focused on inspections, Maria is the champion
key_quotes: dad we almost lost our license over this

transcript: Call with United Refrigeration, commercial refrigeration and HVAC for restaurants and grocery stores. Guy named Steve, service manager. They're part of a bigger company, like 200 people total but Steve's division is about 40. Running FieldEdge right now and honestly seemed pretty satisfied. Main thing he wanted to know was whether we integrate with their parent company's ERP which is SAP. Told him we have an API but not a native SAP connector. He said that's probably a dealbreaker because their corporate is pushing everyone onto the same systems. Said he'd pass my info along but didn't sound optimistic. Probably not going anywhere but I'll follow up in a month.

Really promising call with Comfort Systems out of Chicago. Full service HVAC, residential and light commercial, about 55 people. Talked to the GM Rachel and their dispatcher Kevin. They've been on Service Fusion for three years and are completely fed up. Rachel listed like ten things wrong with it. The dispatching is clunky, Kevin said he spends half his day fighting the software instead of actually dispatching. Techs hate the app. Reports are useless. And get this, they had a data issue last year where Service Fusion lost a bunch of their customer history and it took months to sort out. Rachel said they've already budgeted to switch this year, they just need to find the right solution. She's looked at ServiceTitan but thinks it's overkill for their size. When I walked through our dispatch board Kevin literally said 'oh my god that's so much better.' They want to do a deep dive demo with the whole office team, maybe 8 people. Shooting for early next month. Rachel asked for references from similar sized companies, I'm pulling those together. This one feels really solid, probably close it in 60 days.

extraction.next_step_notes: deep dive demo with 8 person office team, send references for similar sized companies
key_quotes: oh my god that's so much better

transcript: Super quick call, maybe 10 minutes. Elite Plumbing in Tampa, owner named Jim. Tiny shop, just him and like 4 techs. Residential service only. He uses Jobber and loves it, just called because he saw our ad and was curious. Realized pretty quick we're probably too much for a shop his size. Nice guy though, said he might call back if he ever grows. Not worth pursuing.

Had a call with Pacific Mechanical, controls and building automation contractor in Seattle. Pretty specialized - they do BAS installations and ongoing monitoring contracts for commercial buildings. About 25 people, talked to their president David and the IT manager whose name I didn't catch. They're running some industry specific software called Tridium Niagara for the actual controls work but have nothing for the service business side. Using Outlook calendars and texts to dispatch, QuickBooks for invoicing. David said they're growing fast, like 40% last year, and the chaos is getting out of control. The IT guy was really interested in our API because they want to eventually connect our system with their BAS platform to auto-generate service tickets when a building system throws an alert. That's a cool use case actually. They need something pretty quick, David said they're hiring 5 more techs next quarter and can't scale with their current process. Setting up a demo for next week, David said to invite their controller too.

extraction.timeline: pretty quick - hiring 5 techs next quarter
extraction.next_step_notes: invite controller, interested in API for BAS integration
